title: Mapping cli-fi scenarios: Book covers with landscapes, issues, and personal narratives
sections:
Mapping climate change imagery with Google Images

The concern here is with visual representations of climate change. Previous research on climate change pinpointed that there is a role of imagery in the main climate change discourses. For example, climate change representation moved away from naturalistic landscapes towards abstract and symbolic imagery (Hansen and Machin, 2008). Also, people seemed to be dominating the representation, followed by images of climate change impacts (Di Francesco and Young, 2011).

This project brings this question to online imagery and the device that organizes it, in this case Google Images. What does web-based imagery of climate change add to climate change discourse? How does imagery of climate change address these vulnerability indicators? Do we see adapted or vulnerable landscapes? Is the issue humanized (showing people, animals and landscapes) or quantified (in scientific stats and graphs) in imagery?

We find that the most dominant subsets of climate change related images according to Google are “landscapes”, “science”, and “people[a]”.

[b]

Figure 1. Mapping climate change imagery with Google Images. Source: Digital Methods Initiative Fall Data Sprint. Date: 21-25 October 2013

How to read the map

The graphic is a treemap, which communicate through a visual hierarchy the distribution of categories in the image set. Those that are more recurrent occupy a larger area in the graphic.

How the map is built

Google Image Search is queried for the term [“climate change”]. The top 1.000 images outputted by the engine are manually analysed and categorized. Each category is assigned a value corresponding to the number of images that refer to that topic and is visualized in a treemap.
